titleInfo.title: Correspondence from Sarah Hamilton to John Hamilton, March 6, 1864

mods.abstract: Letter from Sarah Hamilton to her husband, John Hamilton. She discusees the loss of the property and the slaves. She bemoans: "How long will this unholy war continue?"

mods.abstract: “March 6th /64 Dear husband Another opportunity having presented itself, I will write you a few lines. Although I have no news; I can write. We are all tolerable well at present; & doing as well as can be expected under the existing circumstances. I was glad to hear from you; Bro Milrner [sic] said he heard from you a few days before he came up; he came up Saturday & is with us tonight but will start early in the morning. I received a letter from Tommie today by flag of truce dated Feb.1st you will please forward the enclosed to him. I suppose you have heard that Cary & Lou are living within the lines. Do not grieve at the loss of property & negroes; I have learned to bear it all paciently [sic] & put my trust in God & look forward to a brighter future. I wish you could be at home in peace; How long! Oh! How long will this unholy war continue? Oh that it would cease so that every weary homesick wanderer could return home again. As I’ve no news to write; I will close. May good angels guard your sleeping & waking hours; & may God’s strong arm be ever around you is the heart felt prayer of your. Devoted Wife S. A. H. Harriet & Family are all well & send love to Fred & Marsh. Please to forward the enclosed letters to Albert D & Tommie & Selma”

titleInfo.title: Civilian Life in the Civil War

relatedItem.abstract: The items in this collection offer new perspectives into the lives of numerous non-combatants during the Civil War in Tennessee and throughout the southeast. The correspondence and primary writings touch on several themes relating to the home front, including the diverse roles of women, the relationship between occupying/invading forces and civilians, personal beliefs regarding secession and the war, and the effect of the war on African American Tennesseans. These sources can offer the public a lens into the lives of many Civil War non-combatant men and women, a subject of increasing importance in Civil War scholarship...
